ORAL ANSWERS TO QUESTIONS

TACKLING TRANSBOUNDARY HAZE

     1.  Mdm Ho Geok Choo asked the Minister for the Environment and Water Resources in light of the recent haze situation (a) what help has Singapore offered Indonesia in battling the fires; (b) whether Singapore with other ASEAN member states will push Indonesia to ratify the 2002 ASEAN Agreement on Transboundary Haze Pollution; and (c) how can the expectations of Singaporeans on air quality and the environment be managed.

     2.  Er Lee Bee Wah asked the Minister for the Environment and Water Resources with the arrival of the transboundary haze (a) what is the Ministry doing to engage the neighbouring countries on managing the hot spots; (b) what is the long-term solution that is being mapped out with neighbouring countries; (c) how has the haze affected the health of older Singaporeans; and (d) how has the haze impacted on our economy, in particular tourist arrivals.

     The Minister for the Environment and Water Resources (Assoc. Prof. Dr Yaacob Ibrahim): Mr Speaker, Sir, may I have your permission to take Question Nos. 1 to 2 together?

     Mr Speaker: Yes.

     Assoc. Prof. Dr Yaacob Ibrahim:  Sir, the transboundary haze creates health problems for our citizens and has wide-spread implications on our economy, tourism and the transportation/aviation industry.  The elderly, especially those with asthma or a pre-existing heart or lung disease, may suffer from chest discomfort or breathing problems such as shortness of breath, coughing or wheezing.  Prolonged periods of haze also

Column: 1452

lead to economic losses for Singapore. The losses are from a rise in hospitalisation and treatment costs, losses in tourism, losses in productivity because people take time off from work and losses in recreational opportunities.

 

     As the period of haze was short this year, any impact on our industries, including tourism, would have been minimal.  However, if the haze were prolonged, there would have been adverse impact on economic activities and health, as was seen in the 2006 haze episode.

 

     Sir, we thus take a serious view of the haze situation.  To minimise the adverse impacts of smoke haze on Singaporeans, an Inter-agency Haze Task Force (HTF) has been established since 1994 to co-ordinate the national action plans to mitigate the impact of haze and put in place measures to inform the public during a smoke haze episode.  For example, hourly updates of the three-hour Pollutant Standards Index (PSI) and the relevant health advisory are given when the haze worsens.  When the PSI reaches the unhealthy range, which is above 100, a dedicated hotline will be set up to answer any queries from the public. When the PSI exceeds 150, the public will be advised to use face masks. When the reading reaches the hazardous range, which is above 200, the HTF will consider stoppage of outdoor activities and closure of schools.

 

     Since the 2006 haze episode, Singapore has actively promoted regional and international efforts to address the haze problem.  That year, Singapore initiated the Sub-regional Ministerial Steering Committee (MSC) on Transboundary Haze Pollution comprising Brunei, Indonesia, Malaysia, Singapore and Thailand to enhance haze collaboration in the southern ASEAN region.  The MSC has met 10 times since then.  One of its objectives is to assist Indonesia in implementing its Plan of Action (PoA) to

Column: 1453

combat haze.  The MSC closely monitors the hotspot situation in the region.  The MSC has organised forums that raise awareness among international organisations, non-governmental organisations and the private sector on the need to share expertise and offer resources in addressing land and forest fires.

 

     On the bilateral front, our collaboration in Jambi province has progressed well.  Eight action programmes, covering initiatives ranging from haze monitoring and assessment to fire fighting and suppression capabilities as well as capacity building on sustainable land-farming practices, have been completed since 2007.  Thus far, we note that the number of hotspots have been low in Jambi Province and, in particular, Muaro-Jambi Regency, relative to other fire-prone provinces and districts in Indonesia.  Singapore’s initiatives are being implemented in these areas.

 

     We are thus heartened that our efforts over the last few years have contributed towards addressing the haze challenges in Indonesia.  We believe it is important to replicate the good experiences gained from the Indonesia-Singapore collaboration in the Jambi province.  This could be achieved by continuing to organise forums that can help facilitate exchange of experience and best practices between local governments from the fire-prone provinces as well as with regional NGOs, international organisations and think tanks.

 

     On 13th October this year, I attended the 6th Meeting of the Conference of the Parties to the ASEAN Agreement on Transboundary Haze Pollution, which was held to review the national, sub-regional and regional activities to address land and forest fires in the region.  We cautioned environment ministers present that periods of dry conditions may occur, and

Column: 1454

urged ASEAN member states to remain vigilant and to continuously monitor as well as implement haze prevention activities.

 

     Together with the other environment ministers, Singapore also urged Indonesia to ratify the ASEAN Agreement on Transboundary Haze Pollution.  With Indonesia remaining the only ASEAN country yet to ratify this Agreement, we will continue with our ASEAN neighbours to call on Indonesia to consider doing so expeditiously.

 

     When Malaysia and Singapore were struck by haze on 19th October, I wrote immediately and followed up with a call to Indonesia’s State Minister of Environment Professor Gusti Muhammad Hatta to register our concerns on the worsening haze situation.  I was assured that Indonesia had sent a team of officers to the areas affected by land and forest fires to coordinate the fire-fighting efforts on the ground.  I also reiterated our offer of assistance to augment Indonesia’s fire-fighting efforts if needed.  On 24th October, the air quality was back in the good range again as the fires subsided in Sumatra.  Indonesia has therefore made commendable efforts to prevent the regional haze situation from worsening this year.

 

     Singapore is currently chair of the MSC for two years until 2012. We will use our chairmanship to work more closely with our regional neighbours to put in place more measures to prevent potential land and forest fires.  This will avert the need for huge resources required by affected countries to tackle the problems after transboundary haze occurs.

     Er Lee Bee Wah (Ang Mo Kio):  Thank you, Mr Speaker, Sir.  We are lucky that for this round, haze visited Singapore for a very short period.  I have two supplementary questions for the Minister. 

Column: 1455

In view of the constant remark by Indonesian politicians that we should be grateful for the oxygen provided rather than complain about the haze problems, does the Minister think that Indonesia has the political will to solve the haze problem?  Question two:  despite the various reminders, telephone calls, cautionary notes that Minister gives to his counterpart, does he think that these have been effective?  As what we can see – and if I may describe their attitude by using a Malay proverb – bagai mencurah air di daun keladi.  Literally translated, it means "pouring water on yam leaves" which is to say it is of no use.

     Assoc. Prof. Dr Yaacob Ibrahim:   Sir, as to whether or not they have the political will to solve the problem is not something for me to answer.  We know for a fact that the Indonesian government has a clear plan of action to cut back the forest fires in 35 fire-prone provinces across Indonesia over the next five years.  As I have mentioned in my reply, what we want to do in the ASEAN region is to work with Indonesia to help them to implement those programmes.  In fact, they have called for assistance across the ASEAN countries in order to implement the plan of action.  As to whether it is being executed on the ground, this is a matter which we have to ask our Indonesian colleagues to clarify.

 

     Our relationship with the Indonesian government in relation to our joint project in Jambi has been a good one.  We have close collaboration not only with the central authorities but also with the provincial authorities.  As I mentioned in my reply, that has helped to reduced the hot spots in the Muaro-Jambi Regency.  So it shows that they have a plan of action and there is collaboration with the regional countries. It shows that it can be done and we can solve the problem together. 

 

     As to whether the reminders have been effective, I suppose the answer is

Column: 1456

that we will continue to remind them that they have an obligation to the rest of the countries in the region to do their part.  So I cannot tell the Member anything else, other than the fact that I will continue to remind my colleagues in the region when we meet again in Singapore next year for the 11th MSC Meeting to inform that this is a concern for all of us and that they should do something about it.

     Mdm Ho Geok Choo (West Coast):  Thank you, Sir.  I have three supplementary questions.  One is: has Singapore considered cloud-seeding as a solution to the haze problem and, if it has, would it offer the same expertise to Indonesia?

 

     Secondly, during the haze Singaporeans tended to stay indoors, shut their windows and for better ventilation, Singaporeans would switch on fans and air-conditioners.  I wonder whether a study has been undertaken to ascertain whether there is a spike in electricity bills during the haze situation?  Will the Government consider giving electricity rebates to cope with higher electricity bills when the haze prevails in Singapore?

 

     Thirdly, what legal rights do average Singaporeans have against transboundary pollution like the haze situation?

     Assoc. Prof. Dr Yaacob Ibrahim:  Sir, to answer the last question first: as neighbours in the region, we have a right and that is why there is an agreement – the Transboundary Haze Pollution Agreement – which all the nine countries of ASEAN except Indonesia have signed and ratified.  If Indonesia were to ratify the haze agreement, which has already come into force, it can be fully implemented and therefore, we can monitor the situation.

 

     Cloud-seeding is normally used whenever you want to have rain.  In this particular instance, of course, if there is rain it would help in terms of easing the haze. 

Column: 1457

We have done our internal studies and have found that cloud-seeding is not very effective even for rain-making purposes in Singapore.

 

     As for electricity bills, we have not really monitored it.  And as for the rebates, I think the Member knows the answer – it is a flat "no" [Laughter].  The most important thing is that Singaporeans must continue to prepare for this eventuality and make the necessary adjustments.

     Mr Speaker:  Er Lee, last question.

     Er Lee Bee Wah:  Thank you, Mr Speaker.  I would like to ask the Minister this: can we bring this issue to international organisations like the World Health Organization (WHO) because any prolonged haze will affect many Singaporeans' health?

     Assoc. Prof. Dr Yaacob Ibrahim:  Perhaps the Member can ask the Minister for Foreign Affairs when he answers the third question after this.  The MSC Forum was first organised in Singapore in 2009 and we are going to continue with the MSC Forum.  The advantage of the MSC Forum is that it is open to the international organisations, the NGOs and the think tanks.  This will allow international organisations that have an interest to come into the region and work together with the regional partners.  So, I think that is a very good platform for us to share best practices, clarify the matter to the international community so that help can be made available in tackling this problem.

Column: 1457

HAZE AND FOREST FIRES

(Commitment from Indonesia)

     3.  Mr Michael Palmer asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs what steps the Ministry intends to take to obtain a

Column: 1458

binding and enforceable commitment from Indonesia for the reduction and ultimate eradication of the haze caused by the rampant burning of the forests in Indonesia.

     The Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr George Yong-Boon Yeo):  As we heard from Minister Yaacob, last month, Singapore was again seriously affected by smoke haze from forest and peatland fires in Sumatra.  There was a day when the Pollutant Standards Index hit the "unhealthy" range.  The haze affected not only people in Singapore and Malaysia.  It affected most of the people in Indonesia who lived closest to the fires.  The haze is therefore a matter of very serious concern to us, to the Indonesians and to the entire region.

 

     On 21st October, Minister Yaacob called his Indonesian counterpart, Pak Gusti, to convey Singapore’s concerns over the haze and to offer our assistance to combat the forest fires.  I spoke to Foreign Minister Marty Natalegawa the following morning to reiterate our concerns and our immediate readiness to assist Indonesia.  Pak Marty told me that he was also concerned about the situation and assured me that the Indonesian authorities were trying to address the problem.  And he stressed the importance of regional cooperation and how it had helped in the past.

 

     The problem is over for this year, in part helped by the wet weather.  When I was in Hanoi for the ASEAN Summit and other related meetings, I thanked Pak Marty for Indonesia's cooperation.

 

     Given that the haze does not respect boundaries, it is imperative that regional countries continue to work closely together on this issue.  Singapore and Malaysia have been collaborating with the provincial governments of Jambi and Riau respectively on various fire and haze prevention programmes.  The Sub-Regional

Column: 1459

Ministerial Steering Committee (MSC) on Transboundary Haze Pollution also meets regularly.  These efforts have helped to mitigate the haze problem in the last three years.  But our experience this year shows that more needs to be done.

 

     The problems faced by the region from the haze led to an ASEAN Agreement on Transboundary Haze Pollution.  The Indonesian government signed this Agreement in the year 2002 but, unfortunately, has yet to ratify it.  It has to be ratified by the Indonesian House of Representatives (DPR).  Although the executive branch of the Indonesian government considers the Agreement important, some members of the DPR have objected to it on the grounds that Indonesia does not benefit sufficiently from this Agreement.  It is hard to understand this argument.  To begin with, Indonesians living in Sumatra and Kalimantan who are badly affected by the smoke haze will benefit most from the Agreement.  We need Indonesia to take the lead on this issue when it takes over the ASEAN Chairmanship next year.

 

     The haze is not only a local or regional issue.  It has a global dimension as well.  The reduction of emissions from deforestation and forest degradation is an important element of ongoing climate change negotiations under the Bali Action Plan called REDD Plus – REDD standing for Reducing Emissions from Deforestation and Forest Degradation, and Plus referring to the role of conservation, sustainable management of forests and enhancement of forest carbon stocks in developing countries.

 

 


Indonesia is an active participant in REDD Plus. The donor countries of this initiative have pledged substantial amounts of money, both multilaterally and bilaterally, to help forest nations reduce deforestation.  An example of this is the US$1 billion bilateral agreement between Norway and Indonesia. This bilateral agreement requires very close monitoring, reporting and verification

Column: 1460

to ensure that the objectives of REDD Plus are met.  At the broader level, Indonesia has also announced a voluntary carbon emissions reduction target of 26% by 2020, and up to 41% with international support.  These emissions reductions are slated to come, in large part, from the forestry sector.  Such efforts by Indonesia to reduce its emissions from deforestation will also help to reduce unsustainable land clearing practices which cause the haze.

 

     For these reasons, we hope to see Indonesia ratify the ASEAN Agreement on Transboundary Haze Pollution soon as it benefits Indonesia, ASEAN and the wider world.

     Mr Michael Palmer (Pasir Ris-Punggol):  I thank the Minister for his thorough reply.  Thus far, the action on Indonesia's part seems to one of putting out the fires rather than preventing them.  Do we know what are their plans to prevent the fires and to penalise the perpetrators who caused the fires?  Also, is this delay in ratifying the Transboundary Haze Pollution Agreement a sign of their seriousness?  Perhaps we can convey to them that they should try harder to ratify this.

     Mr George Yong-Boon Yeo:   We will of course try hard to encourage them to do what is possible.  It is not as if they do not have the plans:  they have the plans.  In previous years, they have made quite big efforts.  In fact, just two days ago, I gave breakfast to GOLKAR Chairman Aburizal Bakrie.  Pak Bakrie used to be MENKO or Coordinating Minister for Social-Political Affairs. He was responsible for helping to combat the haze.  He was telling me how, in one of those years when the haze was quite bad, they got the Russians to help and they leased water bombers from the Russians.  And against the advice of the civil aviation authorities, he decided to take a joy ride to watch the water bombing.  The facilities on the plane were quite basic.  He was telling me that there were no seat belts, just a plastic chair,

Column: 1461

and you were supposed to grab the pilot’s seat while they skimmed the water surface, collected the water, and then bombed the fires.  And this worked.  When I spoke to Pak Marty on the phone, he said cooperation in the past had helped and we should continue to strengthen cooperation.  He said yes, this year is a problem, but in previous years, we had succeeded; so we should continue to work together. 


     They have the plans.  It is a big country, there are many players involved.  Local authorities experience great difficulties.  And it is not as if they themselves want it to happen.  The former Governor of Jambi, Pak Zulkifli Nurdin, is a good friend and knows Singapore very well.  One year, I called him up and said, "Look, we are prepared to help Jambi."  I asked him where he was.  He said he was in Jakarta and could not get back to Jambi because the haze was so bad there!  And here we are talking about a PSI of 100, but for them, it is PSI of 200 or 300.  So our approach should be that the most interested party in solving the haze problem is Indonesia itself, because millions of its own people are affected.  And we should continue to encourage the DPR – the government is very clear about its position, but the DPR has got a life and voice of its own.  And maybe here I can pass the buck to Members of this House. When you meet your counterparts in Indonesia, please also make the effort. 

     Mr Low Thia Khiang (Hougang):  Supplementary question, Sir.  The Minister, in his reply, said that the haze is over for this year.  My question is: how about next year or the year after?  Despite the efforts and the Minister talking to his counterpart in Indonesia, it seems to me that the haze remains and the situation does not improve.  So, does the Minister not think that this is a diplomatic failure on the part of Singapore as well as ASEAN as a

     8.   Mr Terry Lee asked the Minister for Education (a) how effective is the sexuality education programmes in schools; (b) over the last three years, what is the trend in numbers of pregnant students (i) in schools; (ii) dropping out or changing schools; and (c) how can these programmes be further improved.

     Dr Ng Eng Hen:

     MOE regularly reviews the effectiveness of sexuality education in schools and takes steps to improve the content and delivery of the programme.
 
     At the school level, teachers use questionnaire surveys, journal reflections and informal discussions to gather student feedback on the sexuality education programme. Reports from schools indicate that the programme is effective in increasing student understanding about sexuality matters, including the negative consequences of teenage sexual activity.  Parental support for the programme has also been quite positive as reported by the schools.  Although parents have the choice to opt their children out of the sexuality education programme, the opt-out rate is less than 1%.

 

     Over the last three years from 2007 to 2009, there has been a decline in the incidence of STI/HIV among teenagers, teenage pregnancies, teenage abortions and teenage live births.  The teenage pregnancy rate was 2,196 in 2007 and declined by about 4% and 11% in 2008 and 2009 respectively(3).
 
     Not all students inform the school if they become pregnant(4). Thus, we are not able to establish the exact number of pregnant teenagers who have dropped out of school.

However, we have seen a decrease in the overall dropout rate from 3% in 2005 to 1.5% in 2009. Schools work with parents and community partners to support students who are known to be pregnant.  School counsellors will follow up on students who drop out and refer them to community support services.  In addition, the Ministry of Education's (MOE's) readmission policy also enables such students to be readmitted back to the school system.
 
     MOE will continue to review the content and teaching approaches to sexuality education regularly to ensure that it remains relevant to our students. A steering committee which includes medical professionals, educators, health education experts, family life educators and counsellors is chaired by the Director General of Education to oversee this process.  In reviewing the curriculum and implementation of sexuality education in schools, the Steering Committee also consults COMPASS [COmmunity and PArents in Support of Schools] to take into account the views and concerns of parents and the community.  MOE had already started the process of refreshing the sexuality education framework and curriculum to take into consideration societal changes and the new media.


(3) The percentage change is computed as follows: (Previous year's figures – Current year's figures/Previous year's figures)* 100.

PUBLIC AWARENESS OF PROBLEM GAMBLING

     10.   Mr Terry Lee asked the Minister for Community Development, Youth and Sports since the start of the two Integrated Resorts (a) what is the increase in the number of gambling-related problems and what are these problems; (b) how effective are the various education programmes to promote public awareness on problem gambling; and (c) how can these programmes be further improved.

     Dr Vivian Balakrishnan:

     It is still too early to say with any certainty what has been the social impact of casino gambling. The National Council on Problem Gambling (NCPG) has commissioned a gambling prevalence study which should be completed in the second half of 2011. The study is a follow up on the Ministry for Community Development, Youth and Sports' (MCYS) two earlier gambling prevalence studies done in 2005 and 2008.
 
    

Column: 1613

On its part, NCPG will continue its work in two key areas: issuing casino exclusion orders and encouraging problem gamblers and their families to come forward for help.

 

     NCPG has put in place three types of casino exclusions as part of the social safeguards. These are Third-Party Exclusions which ban by fiat all undischarged bankrupts and those on public assistance from the casinos; voluntary Self-Exclusions that allow individuals to restrict their own access to the casinos; and Family Exclusions that empower families to prevent their members who exhibit problem gambling behaviour from entering the casinos.

 

     As at September this year, NCPG has issued over 35,000 Third-Party Exclusion orders. More germane to concern raised would be Self-Exclusion and Family Exclusion. Up to September 2010, there have been over 2,500 Self-Exclusion applications, close to 90% of which were applied after the casinos opened. The NCPG has also issued 194 Family Exclusion orders, and 163 of these were issued since the casinos opened.
 
     NCPG works with Tanjong Pagar Family Service Centre and the National Addictions Management Service (NAMS) to provide, respectively, counseling and treatment services for problem gamblers and their families. From January to September 2010, Tanjong Pagar Family Service Centre has had an intake of 76 new clients.  This is compared to 90 new cases in 2009 and 52 new cases in 2008. During the same period, NAMS had an intake of 130 new clients, compared to 210 new cases in 2009 and 131 new cases in 2008.
 
     The more likely reason for the rise in casino exclusion orders is the greater awareness of the avenues available and willingness to seek help.
 
      When the NCPG conducted its first Public Perception Survey in 2006, public awareness of problem gambling was only 32%. It has since risen to 71% in 2009.  About one in two Singapore residents are also now aware of casino exclusions. NCPG has also reached out to about 1.2 million Singapore residents through ground initiatives such as at the getai since it launched its Know the Line campaign. In order to achieve this, NCPG worked closely with its partners such as the Taoist Federation and the Singapore Buddhist Federation on ground initiatives, which include programmes at the getai during the seventh month Zhong Yuan Hui.

 

     Given the good work done by NCPG, it is not surprising that both casino exclusion orders and help seeking has been on the rise since the casinos opened. MCYS believes they indicate that Singapore residents are responding positively to NCPG's public education efforts.

 

     NCPG will continue its efforts to encourage problem gamblers and their families to consider casino exclusions as well as counseling and treatment.  The Council will also continue to consult stakeholders from religious, community, grassroots and professional organisations as well to enhance its outreach.

SIGNAGE FOR SPEED LIMITS

     11.   Mr Terry Lee asked the Minister for Transport (a) how can the speed limit signage be made more prominent to drivers; and (b) what is the trend of traffic offences relating to speeding over the last two years.

Column: 1615

     Mr Raymond Lim Siang Keat:

     It is important for all our traffic signs, including speed limit signs, to be visually prominent and easily understood by motorists.  Therefore, the Land Transport Authority (LTA) has gradually upgraded our traffic signs island-wide since 2000.  All of our traffic signs are now six to 10 times more reflective than before, and conform to the United Nation's Convention on Road Signs and Signals (Vienna, 1968), with adaptations to suit the local context to ensure that motorists here can understand them quickly and intuitively.

 

     The speed limit for all roads in Singapore is 50 km/h unless otherwise stated by speed limit signs.  These signs are therefore located where appropriate.  While we could theoretically install more speed limit signs to make them more prominent, LTA has to be very conscious that this does not lead to unnecessary cluttering of the motorist's view and the marring of our streetscape.  A balanced approach has to be adopted.

 

     LTA takes great care in ensuring that each and every traffic sign installed is optimally placed for visual prominence, taking into consideration the surroundings and the relative locations of roadside vegetation or other road elements.  LTA also leverages on the regular pruning programme of National Parks Board to help ensure that signs do not get blocked by vegetation growth.

 

     The number of speed violations increased from 158,811 in 2007 to 173,028 to 2009, which is an increase of about 9% over a three-year period. However, we should note that during this period, there was also a corresponding 8.7% increase in the motor vehicle population.

QUEUES AT TAXI STANDS

     12.   Dr Lim Wee Kiak asked the Minister for Transport (a) what is the Ministry doing to ensure that there are sufficient taxis to cope with the rise in demand with more tourists visiting Singapore; and (b) what is the Ministry doing to address complaints about long queues at taxi stands.

     Mr Raymond Lim Siang Keat:

     Sir, the taxi industry was liberalised to allow market forces to determine the pricing and supply of taxis to meet demand. As a result, our taxi industry is a competitive one where companies have the flexibility to increase their taxi fleet and new entrants can enter the market to cater to the increase in taxi demand.  Taxi companies are also able to employ differential pricing through the implementation of surcharges to meet the varying taxi demand at different times of the day and at different locations.

 

     Although it is a liberalised industry, the Land Transport Authority (LTA) continues to monitor the service standards and availability of taxis.  In consultation with various stakeholders, LTA has instituted Quality of Service (QoS) standards that include measuring the call-booking performance of taxi companies.  LTA also monitors the waiting times at taxi stands with high demand that are located in the city and city fringe areas.  The results show that taxi companies are meeting the QoS standards for call booking, and that the average waiting time at taxi stands is generally less than 15 minutes.
 
    

Column: 1617

There were, however, occurrences when the waiting times at some taxi stands in the city area exceeded 20 minutes. These were mainly during the 9.00-10.00 pm period and due to the surge in demand for taxis when shopping malls closed.  LTA recognises that these malls have an interest in managing the waiting times for their customers, and have been working with some of them to look at ways to facilitate improvements at these taxi stands. These include looking at ways to increase the space for taxis to queue, and facilitate the mall management in calling up taxi companies to broadcast to taxis in the vicinity to ply at taxi stands where the queue is long. In addition, LTA works with the taxi companies by sharing the results of waiting time surveys at taxi stands with them for the information to be disseminated to their drivers.

FIRE SAFETY STANDARDS FOR PUBLIC TRANSPORT OPERATORS

     13.   Mr Low Thia Khiang asked the Minister for Transport (a) whether sufficient fire safety measures are in place on public transport; and  (b) what role does the Government play to ensure that public transport operators meet fire safety standards.

     Mr Raymond Lim Siang Keat:

     The Land Transport Authority (LTA) works closely with the Singapore Civil Defence Force (SCDF) to ensure that adequate fire safety measures are put into place to safeguard commuters' interests.

 

     Our public transport infrastructure, such as the Rapid Transit System (RTS) stations and tunnels, as well as bus interchanges and depots, are designed in compliance with prevailing fire safety codes and standards.  For example, the MRT stations are built with non-combustible building materials, and equipped with emergency ventilation systems, fire protection systems and emergency lightings.  Stations are built with adequate exits so that commuters can evacuate from the platform and station within prescribed timings.

 

     Our trains and buses are also designed for fire safety, with fixtures such as fire extinguishers and emergency exits built in to handle fire scenarios. In addition, the bus operators undertake additional safety measures such as using fire-retardant materials for seats and floor mats.

 

     As part of the regulatory standards imposed on the Public Transport Operators (PTOs) to ensure safety of the RTS system, the LTA has stipulated zero occurrence of fire incidents in trains, stations and tunnels to ensure that fire safety standards are observed at all times during the PTOs' day-to-day operations. The Public Transport Council (PTC) also sets Quality of Service (QoS) standards relating to the operational safety of bus services.  If the PTOs are found to be in breach of the stipulated standards, the LTA or PTC may impose a financial penalty according to the severity of the occurrence. 

 

     To further ensure that the PTOs are capable of dealing with a fire scenario, the SCDF requires PTOs to conduct at least two fire safety drills in the MRT stations each year. The PTOs are also required to renew their Fire Certificate each year to ensure each station's fire safety standards are up-to-date. On their part, the PTOs conduct regular training and exercises to continuously update their staff of the latest fire safety standards and practices as well as measures to ensure the prompt recovery of public transport services should a fire incident occur.

SPECIAL IMMIGRATION COUNTERS FOR SENIOR CITIZENS

     14.   Mr Seah Kian Peng asked the Minister for Home Affairs given the ageing population, whether the Immigration and Checkpoints Authority will consider dedicating some immigration counters specifically for senior citizens and their family members.

     Mr Shanmugam:

     In 2009, the Immigration and Checkpoints Authority (ICA) cleared 149 million travellers at our Checkpoints. Since the beginning of 2010, more than 122 million travellers have passed through our Checkpoints. In an increasingly dynamic and complex security environment, ICA faces an uphill challenge in ensuring efficient clearance without compromising security, even while we recognise the extra assistance that some senior citizens may require at our Checkpoints.

 

     ICA has in place several measures for senior citizens who need assistance. For example, ICA will allow a family member to accompany the senior citizen when he is at the immigration counter, instead of the latter having to seek immigration clearance on his own. ICA and the Changi Airport Group have also implemented a new joint initiative called Care@Changi to provide facilitated clearance for passengers with special needs such as pregnant women, travellers with infants, wheelchair-bound passengers and elderly persons. Under this initiative, Changi Ambassadors, who are volunteer youths and retirees, will help escort any such passenger in the queue to the Duty Officer or the air-crew immigration counter for facilitated clearance. 

 

     Given the diversity of travellers passing through the Checkpoints today, the Ministry of Home Affairs (MHA) is of the view that adopting a targeted approach to helping those who need assistance without setting up dedicated counters would be more efficient. We will continue to monitor the profile of our Checkpoint users and review Checkpoint operations to ensure an effective border security regime that is also operationally efficient.

LICENSED MONEYLENDERS

     15.   Er Lee Bee Wah asked the Minister for Law with the rising number of newspaper advertisements offering "soft cash" loans with approval "within an hour" (a) what is the Ministry doing to check on these companies to ensure that they are licensed moneylenders; (b) whether the Ministry monitors the activities of licensed moneylenders; (c) what are the criteria in approving a moneylender's licence; (d) in the past two years, how many moneylenders' licences were terminated because of violation of licensing conditions; and (e) how are licensed moneylenders made accountable for any misconduct.

     Mr Shanmugam:

     By law, all licensed moneylenders must state their business name in their advertisements and marketing material. It is an offence for any person who is not a licensed moneylender to issue any advertisement or marketing material offering to lend money. The Registry of Moneylenders also publishes and updates regularly the list of licensed moneylenders on its website.  Members of the public are advised not to borrow money from any person who does not state his business name in an advertisement, or whose business name does not appear in the Registry of Moneylenders' website list of

licensed moneylenders.  They are also advised to refer suspicious advertisements to the police for investigations. Action is regularly taken by the authorities against unlicensed moneylenders.

 

     On its part, the Registry of Moneylenders monitors the activities of licensed moneylenders. These include inspections carried out at the moneylenders' premises, investigations into complaints as well as joint operations with the Police to ensure that they comply with the law.

 

     Appropriate enforcement action will be taken against moneylenders who are found to have contravened the law.  These can range from a stern warning to suspension of licence, non-renewal or revocation of licence, composition and prosecution in Court.  In addition, the Registry may forfeit the security deposit of errant moneylenders.

 

     In the past year, the Registry of Moneylenders had suspended three licences and revoked one licence due to contraventions of the Moneylenders Act.

 

     As for the criteria for granting a moneylender's licence, the Registry of Moneylenders requires that an applicant and all persons managing the moneylending business be of good character, and fit and proper persons.  They have to be ordinarily resident in Singapore and above 21 years old.  They must also be familiar with the provisions of the Moneylenders Act and Rules.  All persons who will be managing a moneylending business are required to possess a minimum of four 'O' Level credit passes, including a credit pass in 'O' Level English as first language.  In addition, a $20,000 deposit is required to be placed with the Accountant-General as security for the proper conduct of the business.

WORKFARE INCOME SUPPLEMENT PAYMENTS

(Non-receipt)

     16.   Ms Sylvia Lim asked the Minister for Manpower (a) how many workers who qualified for the Workfare Income Supplement (WIS) in 2009 to 2010 did not receive the payments; and (b) what are the reasons that the payments were not received.

     Mr Gan Kim Yong:

     The Workfare Income Supplement (WIS) is automatically paid out to all eligible employees who receive CPF contribution from their employers. For eligible self-employed persons, they are required to not only declare their net trade income for the year but also to make the necessary Medisave contributions in order to receive WIS.

 

     For work done in 2009, 317,000 Singaporeans received WIS.  There are about another 18,000 self-employed persons who have declared their income for WIS but have not yet made their Medisave contributions.  They will receive WIS if they do so by 31st December 2011.  For work done in 2010, self-employed persons have until 31st May 2011 to declare their 2010 income, and until 31st December 2012 to make their Medisave contributions to receive WIS.
